chapter.htmlHeader: How should I assess a suspected undescended testis?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
If there is a suspected undescended testis:

  • Ask the parent/carer about:
    • Whether the baby or infant was born at term or pre-term.
      • In pre-term infants the testis may still be descending at the time of delivery.
      • At term, about 50% of infants will complete testicular descent by 12 weeks after birth.
    • Any known risk factors, including any genetic or endocrine disorders, or history of previous inguinal hernia surgery.
    • Whether the testis has ever been palpable in the scrotum.
      • If the testis is palpable during a warm bath, this may suggest a retractile testis (normal variant).
      • If the testis was present in the scrotum at birth but is no longer palpable, this may suggest an ascending testis.
      • If any lump has been noticed in another location, this may suggest an ectopic testis.
  • Examine the infant or male lying down in a warm room with warm hands, if possible.
    • Inspect the external genitalia to assess for any abnormalities:
      • An undescended testis with hypospadias (penile abnormality) or bifid or unfused scrotum may suggest a disorder of sexual development.
      • Bilateral impalpable undescended testes with ambiguous genitalia may suggest an endocrine abnormality, such as congenital adrenal hyperplasia.
    • Inspect the scrotum for symmetry, size, and colour.
    • Palpate the scrotal sac on each side to assess whether the testis is in the proper scrotal position, its size, and consistency.
      • Occlude the external inguinal rings in the groin with digital pressure (to prevent retraction of the testis with a cremasteric response).
    • If the testis is not located in the scrotal sac and there is a suspected undescended testis, use the fingers to 'milk' from the external ring to the scrotum along the inguinal canal to try to palpate the testis.
      • A possible inguinal testis may 'bounce' under the fingers. Once located, assess whether the testis can be moved to the scrotum.
      • If it cannot be palpated or manipulated into the base of the scrotum, this suggests an undescended testis.
      • If it can be manipulated into the base of the scrotum, but retracts back to an inguinal position after a variable time following manipulation, this suggests a retractile testis.
      • Note: a non-palpable testis when the person is lying down may become palpable in the sitting or squatting position.
    • If there is a suspected unilateral non-palpable testis, examine the contralateral testis.
      • If there is compensatory hypertrophy of the contralateral testis, this suggests testicular absence or atrophy.
      • This may be assessed by comparing the scrotal testis to the glans penis, which is usually approximately the same size. Compensatory hypertrophy is likely if the scrotal testis is larger than the glans penis.
    • If the testis is not present in the scrotum or inguinal region, examine for an ectopic testis in the femoral, penile, and perineal regions.
  • Do not arrange imaging investigations such as ultrasound in primary care if testis is not palpable.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on the assessment of suspected undescended testes are based on the British Association of Paediatric Surgeons (BAPS) consensus commissioning guide Paediatric orchidopexy for undescended testis [BAPS, 2015], the European Association of Urology (EAU) guidelines Paediatric Urology [EAU, 2019], the American Urological Association (AUA) guidelines Evaluation and treatment of cryptorchidism [Kolon, 2014], the Public Health England (PHE) guidance Newborn and infant physical examination (NIPE) screening programme handbook [PHE, 2019], and expert opinion in review articles on undescended testes [Abaci, 2013; Radmayr, 2016; Hutson, 2017; Cho, 2019; Yeap, 2019].

Clinical features on history taking

  • The recommendation to ask about gestation of pregnancy is based on the fact that incidence of undescended testis varies with gestational age, being more common in pre-term infants [Radmayr, 2016]. At term, about 50% of babies will complete testicular descent by 12 weeks after birth. Beyond 12 months of age, spontaneous testicular descent without surgery is unlikely [Hutson, 2017]. This is supported by the AUA guidelines [Kolon, 2014].
  • The recommendation to ask about any risk factors is based on expert opinion in review articles [Radmayr, 2016; Cho, 2019; Yeap, 2019]. 
  • The recommendation to ask if the testis has ever been palpable in the scrotum is partially based on the fact retractile testes may descend during a warm bath [Yeap, 2019]. A previously descended testis that is no longer in the scrotal sac may suggest an ascending testis, and this may be a reason for late diagnosis of undescended testis [Radmayr, 2016; Hutson, 2017]. The information that a lump in another location may represent an ectopic testis is based on expert opinion in a review article [Yeap, 2019].

Clinical features on examination

  • The recommendation to examine the person in a warm environment with warm hands is based on expert opinion in review articles, as cold temperature or anxiety can cause the cremasteric reflex to retract the testes, making the examination findings more difficult to interpret [Abaci, 2013; Cho, 2019; Yeap, 2019].
  • The recommendation to assess the external genitalia to check for signs of a possible disorder of sexual development is based on expert opinion in review articles [Hutson, 2017; Cho, 2019; Yeap, 2019].
    • Bilateral impalpable testes may be a finding in a female with congenital adrenal hyperplasia with extreme virilisation [Hutson, 2017].
  • The recommendations on how to examine for a suspected undescended testis are based on the EAU guidelines [EAU, 2019], the PHE guidance on infant physical examination [PHE, 2019], and expert opinion in review articles [Radmayr, 2016; Hutson, 2017; Cho, 2019; Yeap, 2019].
    • Failure or delay in identification and management of undescended testes may lead to reduced fertility rates or increased risk of testicular cancer in adulthood [Radmayr, 2016].
    • A total of 70–80% of undescended testes are palpable on examination when 'milking' the testis down the inguinal canal [Cho, 2019].
    • The information on when to suspect the normal variant of a retractile testis is based on the EAU guidelines [EAU, 2019] and expert opinion in a review article [Cho, 2019]. A retractile testis is not a true undescended testis as it has completed its descent into the normal scrotal position, but is found in the suprascrotal position [Radmayr, 2016]. This typically occurs after 3–6 months of age when the cremaster and dartos muscles contract, pulling the testis up back out of the scrotum [Hutson, 2017; Yeap, 2019].
    • The information that an initially non-palpable testis may become palpable in the sitting or squatting position is based on expert opinion in a review article [Radmayr, 2016].
    • The information on the sign of compensatory hypertrophy of a remaining testis suggesting testicular atrophy is based on expert opinion in a review article, which notes that there is a compensatory growth stimulus in the remaining scrotal testis that will then enlarge [Hutson, 2017].
    • The recommendation to assess for a possible ectopic testis if the testis is not palpable in the scrotum or inguinal region is extrapolated from expert opinion in a review article [Abaci, 2013].

Imaging investigations not recommended

  • The recommendation not to arrange imaging, such as ultrasound, to confirm the diagnosis of undescended testis is based on the BAPS consensus commissioning guide [BAPS, 2015], the EAU guidelines [EAU, 2019], the AUA guidelines [Kolon, 2014], and expert opinion in review articles [Abaci, 2013; Radmayr, 2016; Cho, 2019; Yeap, 2019].
    • The EAU guidelines do not recommend imaging for the routine evaluation of undescended or non-palpable testes. This approach is supported by the AUA guidelines, which note that imaging rarely assist in decision making.
    • Expert opinion in a review article notes that imaging investigations, such as ultrasound, are not helpful prior to referral, as ultrasound has only 45% sensitivity and 78% specificity for locating an impalpable testis [Yeap, 2019]. Another review article notes that ultrasound lacks the diagnostic accuracy to detect the presence of a testis or absence of an intra-abdominal testis [Radmayr, 2016]. An additional review article notes that pre-operative imaging does not alter surgical management [Cho, 2019].
